awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds several research projects in economic theory. Each project examines a specific question about the implications of self-interested behavior. The first project will help us understand how reciprocal altruism leads to cooperation in communities. The second project focuses on how to best structure apprenticeships and traineeships. The third project examines two different models of how individuals make decisions between choices. Taken as a whole, this research will help us understand how societies build cooperation; how to best train individuals for jobs in fields such as law, medicine, academia, and skilled trades; and will improve foundational models used in macroeconomics, finance, neuroscience, and psychology. 

The first project focuses on self-interested cooperation and introduces a new class of models of anonymous interaction. The project contributes both to the theory of repeated games and to the design of reputation systems. The project on apprenticeship employs contract theory and optimal control theory to understand key empirical features of apprenticeships as well as the implications of possible government regulations that would reduce apprentices’ hours and increase their pay. The project on choice under uncertainty will apply machine learning methods to experimental data to develop better models of choice under uncertainty. The second part of this final project will develop identification, estimation, and testing results for the drift diffusion model which is used to explain the observed correlation between probability of choice and time to decision.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

The grant supported work on the following topics.

1. Cooperation in Large Communities In many settings of economic interest, partners are not fixed, and instead individuals interact with
 different partners over time. Moreover, people
 often have fairly limited information about the past play of their
 partners, and little to no information about the play of people with
whom their partners previously interacted, and yet sometimes they are still   able to maintain more efficient outcomes than consistent with myopic incentives.  The project characterized when cooperation can be supported with various sorts of ``record systems;" this is of interest both descriptively and for the design of reputation systems in onlime markets.

 

2. Apprenticeship Contracts  Many employees go through an ``apprenticeship'' stage where they work long hours and acquire
knowledge and training from their employers---e.g. law firm associates, medical residents, and post-docs. My work explains this as the result of the apprentice's  inability to  make payments up-front or to commit to remain in the
apprenticeship after being trainedd. Importtantly, it assmes that  the rate of knowledge transfer   is  subject to a  learning-by-doing  constraint: the speed at which the agent can learn is bounded by a function of how much practice (with e.g. blacksmithing or surgery) they are allowed  to do.  We show that the optimal contract has two regimes: initially the  learning-by-doing constraint binds and then it becomes slack, as with  PhD programs where students are initially fully devoted to learning, and then split their time between TA/RA work and their dissertation.  We show that optimal regulation must allow for some degree of artificially-slow training to aid consumption smoothing, and that minimum-wage requirements can  backfire as they lead to slower  training.

 

3. Individual Choice The project supported two sorts of work on individual choice. One was a specific model of values for  lotteries (i.e. ditstributions of money payoffs, like 2/3 chance of $2$ and 1/3 chance of $0$) that  (unlike past empirical work) incoporoates the fact the people typicaly prefer simpler lotteries to more complicated oen with the same expected value. The other ort of work is  methodological,  on how to compare various models that have different numbers of parameters and differing amounts of flexibility: if  one model fits better than another is it because it better captures what is really going on or because the model is so flexible it could fit any data at all?

 

4. Learning by Misspecified Agents  People often have  have oversimplified views of their decision problems that do not account for some key features.  environment that do not include the true data generating process for their
observables, and such ``misspecification'' can lead them to maintain incorrect beliefs about the consequences of their actions even when they have lots of data. One part of this project provided the first general characterization of the long-run implications of this bias; a second paper proposed a criterion for how and when people might  replce their misspecified model with a better one.

incorrect views of the world despite abundant data. For example, they might believe ignore the fact that their actions change the distribution of outcomes,or they might believe that a fair coin that has come up Heads several times in a row is now more likely to come up Tails. My work provided the first general results on the long-run outcomes of 

\begin{itemize}
\vitem Belief that taxes are linear in income when they are not;

\vitem Belief in the ``law of small numbers'' and the gambler's fallacy;
\vitem ``Causation neglect'' about the impact of actions on outcomes;  
\vitem Ignoring informative signals in the belief that they don't matter.
